Comment: Good article Mr. Dingman.  The legislative system in Alaska is badly broken.  Simply changing the players is not the total solution if they don't follow their own procedural rules and instead continue to favor a standing caucus based on "traditions" instead of those written rules. 
 This standing caucus system has created a "legislature within the legislature".  Anyone from any party can join as long as they "behave".  
 Voters must ask these candidates if they will join a standing caucus that demands "lock step" voting for a final budget regardless of sustainability and to follow leadership on all procedural votes used to quash suggestions from non-caucus members.  Also will the candidate support the current legislative exemption from state open meeting law?  
Finally, great photo of the clown.   I particularly enjoy the irony that the clown in the photo is not smiling which means the photo could actually be a legislator on the way to the capital.

But I wanted to see Grosse and Henry more clearly, and I felt that they were overshadowed, especially by the balcony set and certain staging techniques. While fine in the first act, the transitions were jarring in the second, especially when Blanche changes for her birthday dinner. And the flower woman's calls almost completely drowned out Blanche and Mitch's pivotal fight. This may be a fault of expectations mostly—I've seen PCS create extravagant sets that still le the characters shine (Great Expectations). They can do better than this.

Comment: Eugene Building Dept. decades ago put up a huge resistance to people trying to turn garages into accessory units, to convert space or to add an accessory unit. It may have lightened up but building costs can be steep. A woman who had been a state building inspector informed me of her futile attempts.

Airbnb is enticing people to rent rooms or attached units for prices higher than monthly rentals: $25-170 a room a night per web site for our area. Buyers are moving here from CA and elsewhere saying that they want a place to rent to .. Airbnb travelers. 

Perhaps we could tax landlords temporarily and Airnnb to raise $ for affordable housing to rent or buy.  Since over 50% of housing is non-owner occupied, could we design a financial vehicle that would relieve some of ownership responsibilities but still provide a long term income? Many older homes have lead in the pipes, lead paint, asbestos in acoustic tiles, textured ceilings and other issues that non-occupying owners tend to ignore.

Comment: Which is why the countries with the best environmental protection laws also have the highest per capita incomes in the industrialised world?

According to your theory, Switzerland, Denmark, Sweden and Finland should be impoverished low growth countries; whereas Venezuela, Nigeria, Indonesia, and Burma should be among the richest countries on Earth.

Yet this is demonstrably not so.

Perhaps you should re-examine your (baseless) theories?

Perhaps the truth is that environmental law is all about forcing the internalisation of negative externalities, and it is a fundamental truth of economics the forcing internalisation of negative externalities is equivalent to eliminating subsidies - which always, always, always, makes and economy stronger and richer.

The harsh economic truth is that, unlike Norway, given the squandering of the heritage trust funds in Alberta and Saskatchewan, Canada would almost certainly be better off without the oil industry.

Comment: When you deny climate science you are dismissing almost every scientist on your list. You refuse to believe that, but it is still the truth.
To quote Doctor Neil De Grasse Tyson: "It's basic physics, if you keep adding energy to a system and reduce the rate at which energy can escape the system will get hotter".
There is nothing, nothing that you can possibly say that will get around that. For climate change to be wrong, the entirety of physics must be wrong - right down to the most basic laws of thermodynamics.

As far as claims go, there is hardly a more extraordinary one you can make than 'fossil fuels are not warming the planet' - and it requires therefore, equally extraordinary evidence to even be considered likely.

Comment: I applaud these efforts by PSE to help our communities be more resilient after disasters like storms and earthquakes.

However, community generators will serve a small percentage of the population after a large earthquake that is very possible in coming decades.  PSE could do more to make sure we have a resilient power grid.

Cities like San Francisco are modernizing their power grids by incorporating solar panels and batteries.  These will provide power even if long power lines connected to distant power stations fail.  This is the "next step" in grid technology that is being designed for Puerto Rico after Hurricane Maria destroyed their poles and wires.

Bellevue should be innovating and planning for power grid resilience to save lives.

Comment: girlatsea, I don't see any links or references to actual research that might prove your point. And I don't understand how sterilizing or removing a feral cat from the population can be more effective than simply removing the cat and euthanizing it. Some (many?) people who try to adopt feral cats release them back into the wild, just like some people who buy kittens leave them behind when they move or become adults. You have to sterilize almost all the cats in a large area (not just a local "colony") to reduce population growth. That goal has never been achieved. 

TNR proponents like to cite a few instances where a "colony" declined or temporarily disappeared, but these "successes" all seem to refer to the last of the original cats dying of old age (or killed by a car or whatever), and don't account for new cats entering the population through reproduction, immigration from nearby areas, or illegal release.

Comment: Of course, your are free to reject whatever you want, but my suggestion that the overwhelming majority of scriptural scholars (Catholic, Orthodox, and mainline Protestant) do not regard the Gospel as history in our modern sense is not a statement of opinion, but a statement of fact--in the precise sense that it can be verified or disproved be empirical research. 

May I give you a widely accepted example?

The synoptic gospels follow the same basic outline established by Mark. When one systematically collects all of the synoptic material shared by Mt and Lk but not Mr, we find almost exclusively a set of sayings of Jesus, and the bulk of that material is collected in The Sermon on the Mount in Mt and in the Sermon on the Plain in Lk (the long dialogue between Jesus and his disciples as they march from Galilee to Jerusalem for the passion). The majority of modern scholars agree that these Mt and Lk shared saying of Jesus existed as a separate collection not lost that is called "Q" cont.

Comment: It seems like you have to brush up on your math skills.  Prices weren't up "another 10%". As for the rest of your post, your analysis is overly-simplistic.  Banking on housing prices rising becuase "people want to move here" is quite naive.  People have been moving to Canada or Toronto (depending on what you call "here") for a long time, and immigration levels have been stable for the last couple of decades.  There is no new catalyst that is changing anything now.  

Prices are on the way down.

Comment: My experience with taxis is bad. You call and you never know when they will come. You watch the clock anxiously wondering if you're going to miss your flight. Taxi's are usually some dingy old car with seats with no support.  The drivers are not friendly.  Not so with ride sharing services.  Uber and Lyft rides are automatically charged to your credit card. No fumbling with cash or swiping your card, necessary.

I suggest you give them a try. I'm sure you will find it a better experience than a taxi.

Comment: Where do you dig up this crap, Agirl, and why do you buy into it? Do you have a clue?

True, the segregationists in Congress and Southern state government were Democrats out of tradition, but they were called "Dixiecrats" to distinguish them from progressive Northern Democrats in the FDR mold. Lyndon Johnson was a Texas Dixiecrat and known bigot who nevertheless nurtured and signed the Civil Rights Act of 1964, which killed Jim Crow, and the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which largely ended black voter disenfranchisement, primarily in the South. After 1964 and particularly after Lee Atwater's Southern Strategy got Reagan elected, Dixiecrats switched their party loyalty to Republican. Today their are very few Democrats in Southern state government.

Your revisionist history is garbage, crafted to lure the ignorant toward racial hatred by making progressivism out to be evil. You are on the side of bigotry.

Comment: The SCC decision was driven by a technicality...that Kadr was a Canadian citizen.   This is the underlying issue which needs to be addressed.

In most countries around the world, if a citizen takes up arms against their own country, fighting their own soldiers, then this is considered treason.  In many countries, treason is punishable by death.   

Why not strip citizenship for those who become combatants fighting against our nation?  They've made their choice to turn their backs against their homeland.  Why should they subsequently hide behind the citizenship they rejected to lay claim to protections and compensation?

The government, and commentators, like to emphasize that Canada is a land bound by rule of law.  As the law is currently written, perhaps there was no choice.  But let's do something to change the law.  If you are a terrorist and combatant, you relinquish your citizenship.  Then we wouldn't have to protect and compensate terrorists like him.

Comment: What numbers exactly are you using?And from which decade? They certainly don't jive with the ones I've seen, or perhaps it's the analysis that is flawed. Realistically, numbers are nothing more than collected metrics used to test and support or refute a hypothesis. They can be extremely misleading, sometimes purposely so to support an agenda based on the hypothesis. For instance, telling me that unemployment is falling. You do recognize those that have quit looking for work don't get counted right? Also, replacing a $30/hr job with $15/hour job increases employment, which does no good if the mean standard of living requires a $20 an hour job. A simple made-up example granted, but true to concept. This isn't a simple question when one factors in other quality of life indices such as access to healthcare, percent of the population imprisoned, educational opportunities, access to basic needs and services (clean water being an example), etc. What about the other metrics I asked about?

Comment: This has been discussed on numerous Bothell Facebook pages for some time, and nearly 100% of the comments are positive.  There's also an online petition with 113 supporters who have signed it.  Making the name Pop Keeney Memorial Stadium has nearly everyone's approval. 

However, it's very sad to hear that the Pop Keeney family doesn't want to be associated with the Northshore students who gave their lives to our country.  The grandson of Pop Keeney says he wasn't a Veteran, and the wife of the grandson is worried that the name will be totally changed.  

Nobody wants to eliminate the name, we in fact would like to honor Pop Keeney in a way he has never been honored before.  We're proposing that the name be Pop Keeney Memorial Stadium, honoring both the Northshore students who went through the school system, as well as Pop Keeney himself.  

A gorgeous monument could be constructed just outside the gates with two granite plaques, one for Pop Keeney, and one for our fallen classmates.

Comment: She's right and I'm reminded how I could just kick myself for not taking advantage of an employer's offer to do this when I had the chance. I was cutting off my nose to spite my face: I had come to dislike the employer and was planning to leave, I had issue with their ethics so didn't trust where they'd invest my money and so on. 

But basically I passed up on free money for the remaining time I was there - all I had to do was invest as much as the maximum they were willing to match.  Another colleague of mine left shortly before I did and totally reaped the benefits.  

So my advice to others in my boat:  don't say no!  Just make sure to read the small print: what happens if you leave before the year's cycle is up and do they let you invest the money anywhere or do they have their investment plan.  You can work with all of that.

Comment: Let's start with increasing med school enrollment - that will take several years before the effect works its way thru the system.  But remember it's not just med school spots. It's internships.  We already see students finishing med school that can't find an internship (and if they have to go south of the border to do so the odds are they're not coming back).

And simply increasing the supply of doctors won't alleviate the billing problem - instead of having a few doctors that bill large amounts you'll have more doctors that bill lesser amounts.  But the total cost to OHIP will be the same.

As others have pointed out, it's quite common for doctors working in a clinic to submit all their charges under a single doctor's billing number - that simplifies things for both OHIP and the clinic but it does make it look like that doctor is billing very high amounts.  They're not.

Comment: Agree there should be capital gains tax on personal residence, but perhaps income tax should be lowered as the government collects more revenue through capital gains taxes.
As Doug Porter pointed out - someone considered a 1%er for tax purposes can barely afford a home in Toronto. That seems crazy that a so called 1%er is taxed at the maximum rate while someone making a $1 million gain on their house pays 0 in tax on the gain! There is no reason to further incentivize home ownership these days as we have excess demand and this exemption is likely often abused.
We may also need to reconsider additional taxes on households owning $1 million+ homes who consistently report minimal income (e.g., foreign buyers) - taxes to ensure they at least pay their share for healthcare, public infrastructure, kids' schooling, etc.
Disagree that the rate should depend on holding period as it may further limit supply as it incentivizes holding. If anything, rate could depend on % gain, like income tax.

Comment: T. gondii oocysts persist and remain infectious in the marine environment for at least 4.5 years.  They have contaminated anchovies, sardines and filter-feeding bivalves (enjoy those raw oysters, folks!).  And they are killing thousands of cetaceans, pinnipeds and otters from Arctic Canada to New Zealand, and from Hawaii and California to the United Kingdom.  Canada now requires screening of beluga meat before permitting its consumption by Inuit subsistence hunters, due to increase in birth defects among that people from toxoplasmosis-contaminated belugas.  The  oocysts are likewise contaminating inadequately-filtered above-ground drinking water sources, which has produced outbreaks of toxoplasmosis infections in various regions.  Chlorination does not kill them.

Comment: Thanks Dr. Plant; you spelled it out for everyone who still does not understand that health insurance is not the same thing as health care. We have all been conned by insurance companies into believing that they sell us  "health care" but anyone who has ever had to fight an insurer over paying for needed care knows better. Anyone who has received a letter, as I did, from an insurer, stating that because I suffer from a terminal illness they would no longer pay for doctor ordered care "because I was not going to recover" knows the difference.
Turning Medicare over to "private industry" will be a death sentence for seniors like myself who could never afford to buy private policies and also pay all the other costs for deductibles, co-pays etc., or attempt to navigate all the ways that insurers avoid paying for care. Comment: I agree, let's get the facts straight.

I've done forest consulting work within this monument and noted it's unique nature and high diversity, especially of confer trees. When the monument enlargement was denounced by timber interests, I responded by calculating the potential loss of BLM harvest volume in the two affected districts at around 5%. This is due, in part, to the low site character of much of this land.

The oft quoted 1937 O&C Act described 500 million board feet a year as a sustainable timber harvest. In the 70's and 80's, over twice this volume was harvested from O&C lands. The average annual harvest over the last 50 years has been nearly 700 million board feet. It's time to pay the piper!

So why not leave the monument as is, unlogged in the future, and allow it to sustain other important O&C resources like water and recreation?

Comment: This article makes is seem like everyone is in favour of the practice. For sure it helps employers bring in cheaper, educated labour. But this depresses the salary ranges to the detriment of people already in the Canadian labour market.

I work in the IT industry as a consultant. I not only have to compete with Canadian firms but also against large multinational foreign firms who bring in thousands of temporary visa workers on shore at half the salary. 

Do we have a shortage? I have not seen any stats - just employers saying they can't find people for the salaries they want to pay. Let's see some evidence to justify this policy - and please not anecdotal evidence (like this article) from those who benefit from the temporary visa program.

In my view, the TVP should be for true skilled labour shortage emergencies of a temporary nature. Not wide spread gutting of an industry.

Comment: The trap I constantly see observers falling into is attempting to assess Trump's strategic thinking in various circumstances.  There is one possibility that often goes overlooked: He doesn't have one.  The hazards of inaccurately projecting meaning onto his behavior has three obvious dangers: 

One is that there is a tendency to cut him some critical slack when his actions are perceived as the product of deliberate & careful thought.

The second is that once meaning is projected onto his actions, then that gets ensconced as truth and used for further deeper & even more inaccurate interpretations.

Finally, the third is that it blinds analysts to the possibility that Trump's inscrutable methods are actually as idiotic as they seem at first glance.

Comment: There are the actual documents of Vatican II, which are pretty conservative, and the spirit of Vatican II, which is pretty liberal.
I don't think either the left or the right really accepts what Vatican II really meant to the overwhelmingly conservative bishops who were there and voted on its documents.  

I think those bishops wanted a few changes at the edges: Mass in the vernacular over here, more focus on the poor over there, but NOT wholesale change, as some, like myself, wanted.
Remember, the bishops at Vatican II were mainly appointed by Popes Pius X, Benedict XV, Pius XI, and Pius XII.  
None of those men were liberal, or appointed liberals.
I think people are still chasing rainbows that never existed in the first place.
I finally realized that I was one of those rainbow chasers, and that's why I eventually left.

Comment: Toyota, in conjunction with UC San Diego, developed the scanning phased-array millimeter-wave radar used in its TSS-P pre-collision system.  They developed a custom integrated circuit to get the price down. TSS-P is standard even on lower priced cars like the Corolla and Prius.

Comment: Copper is ridiculously common. Surveys indicate 10^14 TONS of copper in the first kilometer of the Earth's surface. There are other places to mine copper that are much safer to tap into than the Bristol Bay area. Additionally, there has never been an open pit mine that HASNT had a failure and released chemicals into the environment.

Economically, this won't be that good for the state anyway. Exploration for five years means few jobs in the near-term, while oil is expected to rise again. Even if after 5 years the project moves forward, only a 100-200 jobs MAXIMUM are likely. Thats assuming no regulatory delays, lawsuits, etc which will delay it a decade or more. And assumes it can be done without causing job loss due to damages to the fisheries.

The fact is this really isn't a necessary evil. Its bad placement next to a state and global critical resource. We can and should do better on exploring mining opportunities.

Comment: Misleading headline again. It puts the cart before the horse. 

The (limited) multiculturalism we experience is the result of mmigration, not the cause, and it is successful BECAUSE it is limited, i.e. we have not  had the problems of Europe because Ibbitson is right about THIS: "Canada has largely avoided this trap by bringing in new Canadians from around the world rather than mostly from just one region, ensuring genuine diversity." 

YES! The problem in Europe and the US is one huge block from a particular culture not assimilating and forming a parallel, oppositional society in a dual, "us against them" scenario. Comment: The problem with the "civility" system is that the Globe restricts your account if you don't agree with other users that certain comments were "uncivil". But, on the other hand, there doesn't seem to be any punishment for false positives (i.e. flagging comments that didn't bother most people).

Thus, users have a strong incentive to over-flag in order to avoid losing their posting privileges. So you get a race to the bottom, or what civil liberties people call a "chilling effect": people aren't sure where the line is, so they over-compensate.

Comment: If you think putting Alaska Natives in charge of ANY natural resource will provide any degree of protection or conservation, you apparently do not read much. Check out the history of the Kilbuck caribou herd. Or, if you really want an education, go to Bethel in May and June when the Kuskokwim delta is filled with ducks and geese tending their nests. You can watch fifteen or twenty boats go out there every morning and spend the day killing ducks and geese even though it is totally illegal and unethical, until their boats are literally full, then coming back to town, taking a dozen or two home for supper, coming back the next day, dumping the other hundred or so dead birds out of the boat and going back out to blast a couple hundred more. Yep, they are definitely "Stewards of the Land" alright. Or go do a census of game within 30 miles of ANY village in NW or SW Alaska. No moose, no caribou. If it moves, kill it. If it flies it dies.

Comment: A typical lead width in the Arctic can range from a couple of meters to up to six kilometers and stretch for hundreds of kilometers. They account for 2-8% of a of a given area of ocean covered in sea ice. 

Just for grins let's calculate how much area an icebreaker breaks over say a 100 km patch of ocean. The Polar Star has a beam of ~30 meters, 30*100,000 m=3,000,000 m^2. Total area in a 100 km patch of ocean is 10,000,000,000 m^2 which means an icebreaker breaks 3/100ths of a percentage point in ice area. 

Or in other words, two orders of magnitude less than the 2-8% observed lead covered area, so pretty much no effect at all.

Comment: First off, define "developed country." What you undoubtedly mean are a cherry-picked selection of Western European countries, Canada, and maybe Japan.  In any event, pretty much uniformly those countries do not have lower violent crime and homicide rates ("gun death" is a nonsensical metric if talking about overall actual public safety) because of their gun controls (the most severe of which only begin in the 1960's), they had lower rates prior to having any gun controls at all. Cultural differences matter.

Such as the cultural differences that lead most of them to having similar or higher overall suicide numbers than we do. Suicides of course making up more than two-thirds the idiotic "gun death" metric. Of course, even in the US with the expansion of gun rights, the percentage of suicides involving a firearm has dropped.

But facts are hard and people prefer over-simplification.

Comment: No. I'm saying laws that will only be complied by, indeed can only be complied by, by the law abiding -and- which cannot show any success in achieving their claimed goals anywhere they have been tried should not be passed simply to make people feel better.

So, the only people who could be charged are those at little risk of needing to be. The majority of viol crime is committed by people with histories of violence who source guns illegally. Since enforcement is impossible in practice anyway, <200k leos nationwide and 300+M firearms, why waste the time and money? Canada, and every other country cited as having "reasonable gun control laws," demonstrate there are no documented law enforcement benefits to registration. No documented effect on crime rates after passage and no stat sig number of suspects discovered nor crimes solved.

Comment: I ran a volleyball program for the City of Toronto in the Junction for three years and filled the gym two nights a week.  The union staff detested extra work imposed on them to collect a tooney from each player then staying on site their full shift.  The activity took place in the attached school where the school board janitors like us and preferred the activity to other groups that took permits.  However the union staff complained to management that I was a threat and I was let go based on a complaint about me to Toronto Police Services that I followed up to find didn't exist.  After I forwarded the information to Mayor David Miller his staff told me my 'complaint' had been forwarded to the Manager of Parks and Rec who had his underling send me a letter stating the 'issue' with Toronto Police was no longer an issue...
 
After my departure the program collapsed.  It was still scheduled for one night a week but the gym was empty.  That was $4000 dollars of admittance the city lost.

Comment: Ms Lange chose to have her grievance processed in an open session of the School Board.  To my knowledge that grievance was processed, the Board chose to reinstate her has principal of Page Elementary.  That grievance process was closed.  

As a former teacher and former School Board member, I have never heard of a School Board allowing the public to air complaints about an employee in an open session as they did in their "listening session."  Those individuals had every opportunity to file formal complaints regarding Ms Lange's job performance and those complaints would have been (and some likely were} included in the personnel information the Administation included in its recommendation that Ms Lange be terminated.  It was likely also addressed in the grievance hearing.  

It seems the District has decided to declare "open season" on Ms Lange and allow her professional reputation to be publicly besmirched.  The "listening session" was NOT part of the open meeting grievance hearing.

Comment: Hello alanauer,

Yes, I was out of Canada when a group of lawyers falsely swore to the judge that they had served me in Canada with the judge's order, and that in a subsequent telephone conversation with them, I had confirmed that I had received the judge's order.

In fact, I did not receive the judge's order and so informed them 12 times during the phone call that I did not receive the order. After the call they created a formal 'Statement for the Record', swearing to the court that I had confessed to receiving the court order.

I secretly recorded the call, but to date - 7 years later - no judge has agreed to listen to the recording that proves my innocence and that the lawyers lied to the court. You can read the full story and download the court documents at my website: donaldbest (dot) ca

Comment: Your anecdotal evidence does not equal "reality of the market". It just demonstrates their particular situation. You can't draw an inference that their underemployment is due to the nature of their degrees. 
There is no guarantee that your friends wouldn't be even more in debt and still working at Starbucks if they had STEM degrees. Getting hired is about more than just a piece of paper. It's not enough to simply be able to graduate. You have to be able to market yourself effectively too. I submit that your friends are lacking in concrete job searching skills and have settled for the easiest job to land. No one is going to hand them a job on a plate. They need to get creative in order to demonstrate their abilities and they need to grow their networks. Alternatively they could do a 1 year post-graduate diploma program at a college to acquire more practical skills. The reality is that not every graduate is attractive to employers regardless of the degree they hold.

Comment: "...shut it down and die."

Most Catholics don't even know what the Curia is, much less know who is in that institution or group; but you want it dismantled. Maybe replace it with global representatives from the 150 or so National Conferences of Bishops representing 1.2 billion Catholics? I don't know. I haven't the answer except that it will take a long time to dismantle the Curia -- to make the unrigging successful. Bishops can do it by asserting themselves as individual national bodies, but that seems unlikely right now. Some National Conferences of Bishops, of course, are more progressive than others. In the meantime, in dealing with abuse in churches (and everywhere, really), the best route (for bringing about reform) seems to be through local civil courts, sympathetic laypeople and clerics, the press, and Pope Francis. If courts jailed a few bishops, that might help a lot, too.

You do have a good point.  Due process rights are fundamental and they do apply to everyone living in the US. Anyone who takes it upon themselves to arrest anyone else should not be surprised when they are asked to explain themselves in court.

Your father can certainly try and sue them for false arrest and imprisonment, but I don't see anything in the article that would guarantee his success.

Comment: In Gallup polls since they started asking in 1944 until this election, only about 20% of the public has supported the current system of awarding all of a state's electoral votes to the presidential candidate who receives the most votes in each separate state (not mentioned in the U.S. Constitution, but later enacted by 48 states) (with about 70% opposed and about 10% undecided).

Support for a national popular vote for President has been strong among Republicans, Democrats, and Independent voters, as well as every demographic group in every state surveyed. In the 41 red, blue, and purple states surveyed, overall support has been in the 67-81% range - in rural states, in small states, in Southern and border states, in big states, and in other states polled. 

The National Popular Vote bill is 61% of the way to guaranteeing the majority of Electoral College votes and the presidency to the candidate who receives the most popular votes in the country.

He knocked on my door one day to show me and my wife the plans he had for a fence he was thinking of building between our properties. He was concerned that we not have a problem with what we had in mind: and I'm not a person of any particular importance.  

My heart goes out to him. I've had mental health problems myself. 

His father Arthur has shown much generosity to the citizens of Saint John. He has done many good things and my heart goes out to him too. Who can doubt that these matters have not caused great suffering for him too.

I think there are degrees of mental health. The first step on the 8-fold path of Buddhism is Right View - properly appreciating how things are and why. It isn't easy for anyone.

In this case, the act could be committed, but not be a crime if consent was given. That's a pretty fundamental difference. The question was not around whether the act happened or whether the accused did the act, that was far beyond any reasonable doubt. Comment: The media is fixated on whether the President broke the law by obstructing justice. But that is not relevant. The legal jeopardy here is impeachment, not indictment. The Constitution requires impeachment for "high crimes and misdemeanors." The charge of high crimes and misdemeanors covers allegations of misconduct peculiar to officials, such as perjury, abuse of authority, bribery, intimidation, and misuse of assets, as well as ordinary crimes. Did Trump abuse his authority by suborning and intimidating the FBI director? Did he fire Comey for refusing his illegitimate 'request'? If the answer is yes, and yes, then the Constitution requires the House to impeach Pres. Trump. The Constitution does not make it optional, it says the House "shall" impeach for high crimes and misdemeanors.

Comment: Trump: “on healthcare, we have the votes. We can’t do it now because we have somebody in a hospital”

R Senators: 52
Rs needed to pass Trumpcare: 50
Rs opposed to Trumpcare: 3

52 – 3 = 49

Do the math and then tell us whether Trump was telling the truth or not.

It’s likely that more Republicans were opposed, but they were unwilling to go public as long as their “no” vote wasn’t needed to kill Trumpcare. It’s called political cover. 

Senator Thad Cochran, a potenial “yes,” was home recuperating, not in the hospital. If he couldn’t get to the Senate floor to vote, only 2 defectors were needed to kill the bill. Why did everyone wait until Collins became the third “no” to say Trumpcare was dead when Cochran’s absence had already killed it? Or why no news about Cochran flying to D.C. for the vote? Because it wouldn’t have mattered — Republican leadership knew that more “no” votes that would emerge.

Comment: Vigilantism is "taking the law into your own hands." It's not "vigilantism" in any way, shape, or form to ask people, whom you don't recognize, standing in the middle of a neighborhood road, in the dark, in the middle of winter, at 1 am, what they're doing. Nor to suggest, even brusquely, that there are better places to do whatever it is.  

There's also nothing in merely asking people questions, absent you presenting them with articulable, reasonable perceptions of imminent risk of death or grievous bodily harm, that justifies their use of deadly force in response.

Now, if presented with an objectively and subjectively reasonable threat of such force, defending yourself from that threat, within the bounds of the law, is -also- not "vigilantism." "Taking the law into your own hands" refers to enforcing laws, or taking vengeance after the fact, not immediate self-defense.

Anyone who cares enough to make informed, useful comments, please read Andrew Branca's "Law of Self-Defense" first

Comment: This is what I like to call "magic math".  There is absolutely no substance and it's filled with vagueness - more like a PR smokescreen to buy time to go back to the drawing board and come up with a plan that makes sense. In the meantime, they are placating everyone by saying it affects hardly anyone. Therefore, "nothing to see here....move along". Opaqueness creates uncertainty for business decisions.

How is $50K passive income defined? What counts as "income"? What about unrealized gains? What about dividend income & the dividend tax credit? What about foreign dividends & the existing withholding tax? If Mr M. has a corporate holding company for a villa in France which does not generate any passive income....is that exempt? Should he be taxed heavily that he is forced to sell and put the money back into the operating company? What's good for the goose.....

Hold co's with investments are already taxed at the highest marginal rate every year. Tax integration is already in effect.

Comment: I find it depressing that there isn't room for both - that coding must supplant cursive. 

I'm an architect - I know sketching (...cursive) and AutoCAD (coding...). There is a place and a time for each. Sketching can get the required information out fast to the Contractor and we sometimes simply scan in the sketch to the computer drawing set afterward rather than redraft it in CAD.  Clients love a sketch.  CAD is great for repetitive details and coordination.  They supplement each other.  Cursive, in my opinion, is much the same as a sketch. Fast, easy, and individual. 

Human society has been based on handwriting and hand-written documentation for centuries and to simply dismiss it as no longer required is short sighted.  When children learn cursive, it is part of their development in learning hand-eye coordination and it a good early indicator of dyslexia and other visual issues. Cursive is gone from Alberta schools and I think we will be poorer for that decision.

Comment: As a multiuse user of our trails, on foot, skis and bike, I'm sad to say that the majority of cyclists go way too fast, especially on multiuse trails shared by people on foot, skates, skis, etc.  Fat tire, mountain bike, road bike all the same -- most give no warning of their approach from behind.  And, no, I don't listen to music when I ride or walk.  I want to hear what's around me.  Next time you're walking on the Coastal Trail, take note of how much warning time you have when a cyclist overtakes you, especially if your first awareness of their approach is the sound of their tires.

So to the cyclists I say, SLOW down when you can't see well ahead and do more than yell "On your left, " three seconds before you whiz by me.

To everyone else I say, take the earbuds out and pay attention to your surroundings.  You'll live longer.

Comment: There are many valid reasons for taking CPP earlier. That does not mean that everyone should do it, however.

Those who have a choice (meaning that they really don't need the extra money to survive) may decide to deposit all of their CPP payments into a TFSA. You would have to simulate the result of doing that and seeing what amount of income can be produced (and for how long) to fairly compare .

The recent discussion about limits on CPP survivors benefits is a significant reason why people are reluctant to delay

It has always been a math test and guessing how long you may live to know what will produce the most total benefit.

If the CPP would introduce a feature that would ensure that at least 10 years of payments would go the spouse or estate in the event of an early death, people would be more likely to take it later. But there is no guarantee of even one months payment.

Species diversity is way up in older and large critters find the spaces and the selection of food and shelter much more conducive to surviving while we- humans- just find them much more pleasant. It gets better as it ages, but then it gets whacked again.  I worked in the mineral exploration and tree planting businesses for more than 20 years and walked through all sorts of such ground and have seen it all. Comment: The number of people who don't have a clue on this site is staggering. Loss carry froward is not paid by tax payers. It's expenses paid last year that exceed the allowable deductions for that tax year. 

Example. You have a job that pays $1000.00 in December but don't finish it until January. $700.00 was expense, $300,00 was profit. The entire expense is put on last year because that is when u spent the money for the job and the entire income is profit this year because that is when you billed it. Comment: For the record, George W. Bush was President in 1992, and signed NAFTA.  NAFTA is not responsible for all of our ills.  Trade is good for everyone.  As Prime Minister Trudeau said at the North American Summit last month, workers in countries who trade, traditionally are better paid.  The force that has impacted workers in America much more than NAFTA goes back to 1971, when President Nixon ended a Cold War trade embargo against China.  That year we imported $4.7-million in goods from China.   In 1980, China was given Most Favored Trading status.   At that time we imported $15-billion worth of Chinese products.  In 2001, when China joined the World Trad Organization our Chinese imports were $102-billion.  Last year we imported $483-billion in Chinese goods.  NAFTA is small potatoes.  China had willing partners in the American business community who bought cheaply produced Chinese goods for their shelves.  And, their other partner can be found in your mirror.

Comment: I've never understood how hydrogen could be offered as a broad based transportation solution.  The process is complex and very inefficient and may actually be at the same level or less ( ~ 35% efficient) as the ICE process.  In a world of increasingly scarce and more expensive energy, hydrogen would not seem to be suitable for anything more than some niche applications .  

EV ranges of 350+ km and recharge times of < 30 minutes would seem to make hydrogen largely redundant.  

Cheers,
John Meyer

And we wonder why so many kids are unprepared for the real world.

You can register people, but if they haven't already registered - which is very easy to do - is it really likely that they'll vote? Comment: When "accidents" also became part of the standard vocabulary, with the treatise of Guitmond {11th century Spanish bishop}, the way was prepared for the definitive statement on the doctrine of the real presence, by an expression of the dogma of transubstantiation. The first use of this word has been attributed to various theologians of the period, often to Peter Damien {11th century monastic writer and cardinal}, until the Exposition of the Canon of the Mass under his name, where the word occurs, was shown to be a later work. It now seems that Rolando Bandinelli, who later became Pope Alexander III was the first to speak of "transubstantiation" in a work prepared about 1140, although it also appears in a work ascribed to Stephen of Autun from about the same time.

Comment: I disagree. The post war Keynesian boom came to a crashing halt in the '70s as oil shocks and inflation broke the relationship between wages, productivity and prices. 

The fact that these circumstances coincided with a period in history when a mature and organized labour movement that had developed under industrial capitalism was able to flex its muscles to fight to protect workers' wages against inflation doesn't mean that either Labour or the union movement were wrong. It means that capitalism was failing to provide adequately for the people who were doing the work. 

The neoliberal response from Thatcher and Reagan was to break the unions and use monetary policy and high unemployment to tame worker demands — and now, 40 years later, here we are again with capitalism failing to provide adequately for the people who do the work.

Comment: Cook, et al., provided a detailed account of the methodology for categorizing the findings of studies.  Inter-rater reliability was reported as well as the methods used to resolve differences in ratings.  The entire methodology of the study was reported as well as all data analyses.

We don't even know who it is.  No data on inter-rater reliability, no information on methods used to control bias.  Just some "guy" who said he categorized them.

Having served as the primary director of dozens of master's theses, Cook's study would far surpass the minimal standards.  In fact, the authors describe their methodology, their findings, their analyses, and their caveats about the project.

Contrast that with your presentation of "some guy's" categorization of the studies in a comment to a blog.

Comment: Post security concessions do need to be addressed at DIA, but not with this misguided project.

DIA is trying to mimic airports like Heathrow that have huge shopping and dining concessions behind security, but they're comparing apples to oranges.   As long as the trains are there the natural tendency is going to be to get on the train and get close to the gate ASAP.

If they want to address the lack of concessions behind security there are better and cheaper ways to do so.  First of all, get rid of all of the stupid, underutilized bookstores, etc. in the concourses.  You could cut them in half, at least and still have plenty.  Those spaces could be used for bars and restaurants.  Second, DIA's master plan has a allowance for at least two more concourses.  You could build one of them much cheaper than this project.  Build a fourth concourse, move some of the airlines to it, and use the extra gate space in the existing concourses for concessions.  Problem solved.

Comment: The headline is brazen, inappropriate pot-stirring, it creates false news instead of reporting real news.

The headline states: "QUEBEC TOWN rejects plan to build Muslim cemetery in narrow vote."

Hello?

Um, I couldn't help but notice the following, buried deep in the news report:

"The Saint-Apollinaire city council unanimously approved the project but it required a zoning change, opening the door to a referendum. Only those whose properties adjoined the proposed cemetery site were eligible to cast ballots."

Hello?

This was not the QUEBEC TOWN (i.e. city council) rejecting the cemetery proposal, it was a vote of adjoining property owners that rejected it.

Seriously, this is like having a situation where Trudeau, his Cabinet and all MPs of all parties in Parliament voted in favour of a Pearson Airport expansion westward, and then when the proposal was blocked by a zoning vote by an adjoining handful of Toronto business, the headline said: "OTTAWA FEDS reject Pearson expansion".

Comment: Actually, I know quite a bit. Between a good deal of studying as well as living and working in bush Alaskan communities most of my life; I'm pretty sure I know a thing or two. 

Senilicide was a commonplace practice in Eskimo communities prior to the appearance of European cultures. Good, bad or indifferent; it's just a fact. Native communities throughout Alaska commonly raided one another prior to the appearance of Europeans to take women from other gene pools (or so elders I've spoken to in Barrow, Nuiqsuit, and Kaktovik have told me in stories), which in this day and age is called kidnapping and rape. Once again, good, bad, indifferent; I don't care, it's just a fact. White royalty incestuous? How about EVERY royal house on the planet; not just white folks. So your point? Warrior culture? Sorry, Aztec=warrior culture, Eskimo=hunter gatherers (very good ones actually). There is a broad difference in anthropological terms. 

My points are, don't make things up. Accept what was real.

Comment: aiea7, Affordable housing is only a marketing ploy to convince the public to support rail.  Alternately, lots of housing would be built in urban Honolulu if density were increased to allow low rise apartments in areas now designated for single family homes.  The increase in supply would bring down prices, making much of it affordable.  Furthermore, limiting infrastructure to urban Honolulu instead of spreading it out would reduce costs.  If you think that everyone who lives in housing built along the rail line would always take the rail, you are sadly mistaken.  In Hawaii, people love their cars.  More people would commute to town by car, increasing traffic along the H-1 corridor, which is already horrible.

Comment: Thanks to Bishop Braxton for this great article on the museum --I'm inspired to visit it!  I'm wondering why he doesn't mention St. Katharine Drexel in paragraph 15.  She founded the Sisters of the Blessed Sacrament in 1891 and opened many schools in the South specifically for the African-American population because they weren't accepted in the public schools.    Their schools peppered the east coast cities of New York, Philadelphia, Newark, Atlanta, Boston, and more, as well as the Midwest -- Chicago, St. Louis, Cleveland, Cincinnati, and Columbus. The Sisters also established Xavier University in New Orleans, a very prominent institution of the city, which is still in existence. St. Katharine Drexel was canonized in 2000 and her feast day is celebrated March 3.

Comment: The alt-right are just looking for a way to replay the Reichstag fire of 1933. For those who need a history refresher, after Hindenburg appointed Hitler chancellor (when the Nazis only had a plurality of seats in the Reichstag),  the Nazis burned down the parliament building and blamed it on the Communists. The plot involved an actual Communist who was persuaded to set the fire. The Communists were kicked out of the Reichstag, giving the Nazis the votes to pass the Enabling Act, which gave Hitler dictatorial powers. 
Today, some hotheads ( of various stripes) are all too willing to be the stooges of the alt-right by committing ridiculous and ineffective acts of violence that will provide the extreme right elements in the Trump administration with excuses to impose extraordinary measures. Trump must be resisted but violence just plays into his hands. Peaceful protest and civil disobedience is the only viable option.

Comment: Trio of judges highly ethical, June 24, 2016 in Star-Advertiser Letters to Editor

I am writing not as vice chairman of the Honolulu Ethics Commission, but solely as a citizen.
A Star-Advertiser editorial repeated an insinuation that Mayor Kirk Caldwell appointed three retired state judges to interfere with the operations of the commission (“Don’t let city ethics work languish,” Star-Advertiser, Our View, June 17).

That insinuation is false. I personally have known the three judges for more than 30 years and know for a fact they would not be a party to any such thing. In my opinion, they each have the highest personal character for honesty, integrity and moral courage of anyone I know.
I have observed that their decisions as commissioners are always based on the merits and what they honestly believe is fair, just and right.

Michael A. Lilly
Pacific Heights

Comment: Ms. Smith's comments couldn't be more off the mark.Most of the work is not being done on-line. In Toronto alone, there are some 600+ studios recording VO everyday, New York and LA triple that. 
To say that the average rate for VO is $250-$300 is completely wrong. 
For instance, in the last 24 hours I recorded two VO projects. One was for 3 ten second TV spots running in regional US markets. This job paid $1800 USD; 10 minutes to deliver. 
Second project was an e-learning narration for a client of mine. 25 minutes of finished audio took roughly 2 hours to deliver. $950 USD.
$250-$300 is what Voices.com pays talent on average for VO and should not be confused with "real" rates for the service.
I have never heard of a college program  for VO. Voice coaching services are sketchy at best and should be approached with skepticism.
80% of the work is done by 20% of pro VO talent out there on the internet. There may be 3 or 4 in Canada making 6 figures.

Todd Schick
toddschick.com

Comment: You list three questions for consideration about putting in place a permanent shelter. A pertinent question is missing. What is the anticipated impact of a permanent shelter on the number of homeless persons in Eugene? Until this question is answered, plans for a permanent shelter are dubious at best. As Congressman DeFazio said at his August 1 community meeting at Churchill High School, the homeless population is mobile. Cities that increase services can attract greater numbers of homeless persons. In that case, Eugene's current huge problem would become overwhelming. A better approach would be to develop programs that are implemented regionally or nationally.  This is a situation where good intentions are likely to have undesirable consequences.

Comment: Kealohi, the Constitution does not “presumes how it is that they can choose to use the NFL as their stage despite nonownership.”  The First Amendment prohibits the government from interfering in the free exercise of speech and religion, but it does not prohibit owners of private businesses from establishing rules of conduct for their employees.  NFL owners have a right to require their employees, a.k.a. players, to be on the sideline, helmets in hand, standing at attention, and facing the flag during the playing of the National Anthem.  Many people evoke the First Amendment in a private setting, in the belief they have an absolute right to say what they want and speak what they want, but that is not true in a private work place.

Comment: Writing under the headline "numbers don't lie..." Mr Dogterom however conspicuously fails to mention any numbers.  Here are some to fill the hole he leaves.

According to the Independent Electricity System Operator, nuclear provided 60% of all electricity consumed in Ontario in 2015.  Hydro provided 24%. Renewables provided less than 8%.

As for costs, the Ontario Energy Board reports that in its regulated price plan for 2014 to 2015 that each unit of hydro generation cost 5.,1 c/kWhr. Nuclear cost 5.9 c/kWhr.  Wind was more than double these rates at 12.3 c/kWhr. As for solar--out of sight at 47.6c/kWhr.

So Mr Dogterom is right on one thing: the numbers don't lie. What the numbers tell us however is that nuclear and hydro generation provide Ontario consumers with low-cost, carbon-free electricity.  And the renewables industry on the margins is less about harvesting nature's bounty than it is about harvesting the subsidized rates handed out by the ON government.

Comment: Beautiful column Mr. Tice, and the difficulties in  your family story are way more common in American history than most realize.  Your family's history has helped you empathize with the struggles of today's immigrants. 
It is especially touching as many Polish-Americans faced tough times back in those days and were in fact often victims of disrespect, poverty and discrimination.  Their history today is one of  multicultural America's great success stories, yet as recently as the 1960s "Polish jokes" portraying Poles in negative stereotypes were common..  Seems like we always need to have someone to look down upon to make us feel better.

(For those who really  want to know first-hand about the Polish-American immigrant experience, look for the multi-volume set in the  Knight Library "The Polish Peasant in Poland and America" by Chicago U sociologists Florian Znanieki and W.I. Thomas.  Considered one of the first great empirical studies in American sociology)

Comment: Sheesh, this tempest would fain tip the teapot. I mean the bitter disharmony on display here, not that little letter. The letter causes nary a ripple for the powers that be.

The underlying issue--tell me if I'm wrong--is this. Belief in clear, objective rules of sin became a rallying point for rigorists. That belief is in deep trouble. You don't have to be Irish to think up a scenario--several scenarios are well known--where thwarting an ethically considered abortion would be un-Christian. And it's not hard to think of Christian exceptions to the no-communion rule for un-annulled remarrieds (we have a "quote" from You Know Who naming one exception). So good luck with objective rules. Judgment is not ours.

Can we still accompany each other? We've come to the last straws of objectivity, and those are wafting away. Soon all any of us will have left to confront will be our own failure to love. Yikes, I can sympathize! I don't like thinking about that at all.

Comment: If your non-negotiable issue is AUTHORITY, you become part of the problem and not of the solution.

Too many make false gods out of 1) the clarity of authority, and 2) the authority of clarity. 

 They make evils out of ambiguities, rigorous discernments, debates, sciences, and other "sinful threats" to a non-messy, nuance-free, ambiguity-removed order they hope for. Heck, some even demand that the Pope use his "authority" to answer their "yes or no" questions, in their quest to satisfy a driving desire and need for unnatural clarity.

They follow as dogma the dictum expressed by Archbishop Chaput: "Confusion is of the devil."

Comment: MisterAl:  I'm not quite sure whom you're addressing.  However,  one of my points addressed the impact of the Presidential candidate on down-ballot candidates.  Many voters do NOT simply vote "party line", but do look at the candidates, and a strong leader on the ballot sets a supportive tone for down-ballot voting.  It helps to be associated with a "good" candidate and hurts to be associated with a "bad" one.  GOP candidates are realizing just how "bad" a candidate Trump is and, fearing the damage from being associated with him, are distancing themselves.....and wisely so.  There's a real chance that Trump's candidacy may lose the GOP both the House and the Senate.  It's very difficult to lose the Presidency in a "landslide" w/o negatively impacting those down-ballot races..and, at the rate he's going, Trump is headed for a landslide loss.

Comment: President Trump won the election. It is accurate to say that, just as it is accurate to point out that the election was conducted as it has been every election since 1804.

The composition of the Supreme Court - whether it is one Justice or one hundred Justices - is Congress' decision.  There is no legal requirement that the Senate consider a nominee within a particular period of time, or holding hearings at all.

In 1824 John Quincy Adams was elected but Andrew Jackson won the popular vote AND the electoral vote.

In 1876 Rutherford B. Hayes won by one electoral vote but lost the popular vote by more than 250,000.

In 1888 Benjamin Harrison won but lost the popular vote by more than 90,000 votes.

In 2000 George W. Bush didn’t win the popular vote.

The election was a couple of months ago and it's time to put on our big girl and boy pants and get over it.

Comment: My father was a devout Catholic and an avowed secularist. His primary identity was Canadian. I suspect that this is the case for the vast majority of Canadians who identify with Christian religions. Their primary identity is rooted in their attachment to Canada or, as is the case for many Francophones, Quebec. More recently, however, there's been a shift as Canada has seen a growth in immigrants (and their offspring) from other religions, often from regions and/or communities where religion is synonymous with personal identity. One study, for instance, indicated that over 60 percent of Muslims in Canada identify primarily as Muslims rather than as Canadians. For many Canadians this is a troubling trend. As my now-deceased father used to note, the most positive social development he witnessed in his lifetime was the decline in sectarian religious chauvinism in the aftermath of WWII. This is a development a lot of Canadians don't want to see reversed.

Comment: Something like this happened a few years back in Lake Coeur d'Alene in Idaho, but in that one the person with the boat jumped in to save the one who couldn't reach it instead of motoring over and they both wound up drowning. Here the would-be rescuer went to the boat first, and while I know they'll second guess their actions it could easily have been two of them who perished if they hadn't. It's just too easy to not understand that in a lake a boat has so much less of its tangential surface area under the water than a person does, and wind is going to push a boat along much faster than an individual in the water, perhaps faster than that person can swim. You have to anchor your boat first, or swim from shore. And have on that life jacket.

We've all failed to take the worst that could happen into account at some time in our lives, and it's sad to see that in this case it cost a man his life. Maybe if someone hears about it and thinks twice before doing the same it will mean something.

Comment: "From my observed experience when construction slows down, inevitably the country goes into recession, affecting all areas of the economy."

This is the 'chicken and egg' conundrum (which comes first?), though, isn't it? Prior to the 2008/09 recession, Spain was booming primarily as a result of a robust housing construction sector that in large part catered to investors from other parts of Europe. Once the recession took hold, the construction boom collapsed with an effect that rippled through the rest of the economy. The Canadian experience is that housing construction is robust in at least a couple major centres as a result of high immigration and an influx of foreign capital. My suspicion is that the housing construction and price boom will subside if the underlying and essentially artificial external factors that are driving the boom change.

Comment: If you want to know why the  Jones fire is not being controlled any quicker than it is, read it from the Incident Commander's point of view.   https://inciweb.nwcg.gov/incident/5494/
The "critical resources" he is referring to are hotshot crews that have the knowledge and training to burn the indirect firelines that have been constructed in on the leading edge of the fire.  The Jones fire is fifth in the regional priorities (behind a fire far from any population centers on the Colville Indian Reservation) so they are not getting the shot crews need to do the burning and contain the fire.  
Besides having to deal with the heavy load of dead and down and standing dead trees left from the Clark Fire (never salvaged logged because it was in a Late Successional Reserve), many of the logging roads in the fire area had been decommissioned meaning they had to be reopened with heavy equipment delaying line construction that may have controlled the fire at a much smaller acreage.

Comment: EHS '54,  fellow members of the Silent Generation, congratulations to you all!    Good  for you for still meeting , and the idea of the "80th" was just great.    Turning 80 does seem like a landmark.  We realize how different is the world of today  from our youthful experiences.

  Our Marshfield HS class of '54-- your class cohort -- has also been meeting though  our ranks are thinner as well.   We shared so much history- the Depression, the  national unity during WWII, the postwar affluence and conformity.. 
We remember some of you, especially  from those fierce football and basketball games we played those last two  years,  Great rivalry, "Give em the ax the ax' ,We'll take the ax..."
Especially fond memories of Eugene during  the State Tournament.  That WAS a   State Championship game our junior year though!

Those were  golden years to grow up in Oregon, busy years in our little  towns,  lots of good memories.  And some tough ones as well.
    Doug Card, MHS 1954, Pirate forever

Comment: Birds of a feather flock together as the old saying goes.  People want to hold onto the culture they grew up with whether in the 'old' or 'new' country. Immigrants who do not wish to assimilate to the culture of their new homeland can usually be ignored by society if they are few in number but once they become numerous they effect noticeable cultural change. If that change is resented politicians who are willing to slow, stop or reverse the immigration tend to get elected. 

The first rule to follow to be accepted into any group is to agree to the rules of the group. This agreement to abide by the rules may be sincere or insincere. When one becomes a member of the group one either assimilates or can try to change the rules of the group. That is how cultural change happens peacefully. People may fear change but taken in small doses change is often quite palatable, desirable even.

Comment: In all the discussion about allegations deemed unfounded - in fact about most discussion of sexual assault - there seems to be a baseline assumption that any given allegation is true.  We often hear "believe the victim", which prejudges the case.  
The vast majority of society properly finds sexual assault, and the people who commit it, abhorrent.
But where are we going as a society if we say everybody is entitled to due process, and their day in court - unless you're accused of something we really find repellent?  Then we're just going to assume you're guilty unless you can prove that you couldn't possibly be guilty. 
To assume that no accusation is ever a lie, or a change of mind after the fact, is as absurd as it would be to assume all accusations are such. 
Somehow we have to find a balance where we protect victims while protecting due process.  If if were easy we would have done it long ago.

Comment: It would be beneficial if articles like this went into more depth about the differences between Canadian health care and American health care. Knowing such information probably make more Canadians want to keep what we have.

1. Canadain style health care absorbs relatively less of our GDP. From information put out a few years ago I recall the US spends between 50% and 100% more for its health care services.

2. I read a report recently that suggests that in the US as many as 200,000 to 440,000 die each year from botched medical procedures. The report was a few years old but still revelant. In Canada it is estimated that about 150 people died from botched medical procedures last year. I think the reported US numbers are excessive but it points to a serious problem with quality of service.

Frankly, I would prefer to wait a while for medical services in Canada rather than run the risk of dying on the operating table in the US.

Comment: I see that everyone is making basically the same comment, which is that Ibbitson might as well be saying that the only way to populate Mars would be to send people there.  Look, it isn't as if immigration levels in Canada are low.  In fact, a good argument can be made that we are bursting at the seams with immigrants.  But you can't pay people to settle and stay in Atlantic Canada if they can't make a living there, and you certainly can't force them.  Economic growth will have to come from young Atlantic Canadians who decide to stay at home and start enterprises that attract talent, not only from abroad but from the rest of the country.  But the tradition of living on handouts from Ottawa and remittances from Alberta seems too embedded in the collective psyche.  Harper said as much some years ago and was pilloried for it.  People don't like the truth.  A real problem is that the region is guaranteed so many Senate and Commons seats.  How long will people tolerate that?

Comment: Why is anyone surprised?

Trump made a promise to place US interests first and foremost.

He is.

Canada had better get its own house in order, look after its own interests....it should forget about the globalist nonesense of saving the world, placing its  interests before Canada's own interests.

Start off with free trade within Canada....wanting global free trade without having domestic free trade is absurd.

Second start making Canada competitive again, slash taxes, slash corporate taxes, slash energy costs....one notes that Hydro Quebec, as reported in the G&M, is ' building dams to solve US nuclear woes' ...it is building dams on the Romaine River to generate clean inexpensive energy way beyond its own needs...Ontario, in contrast, has, for ideological reasons ended up with a situation that Ontarians pay the highest hydro costs in Canada ( twice as much as do Quebecers) ....at least Ontario is negotiating with Quebec to import it's cheaper hydro.

Comment: American Values are the same as they ever were. The idea of us was inspired by the Enlightenment Age, and I promise you that the statue of liberty was inspired by neither the predation of maniacal sociopathic capitalism nor by attacks on virtue, erecting enslavement, nor burning out our higher consciousness. Everything we are supposed to be is sitting there in our own past. It was attacked endlessly by capitalism for a century and more, but people's hearts have no confusion when they're led to the good.

We've just run this massive experiment to see what happens if we let greed and avarice rule the system and shout down the good and diverse moral voices of our country for nearly forty years. The things that have been done with this system in that time boil blood and blister faces. We never talk about this stuff, just brush it off, and that's because our debate has been astroturfed over badly and it's been going on for so long, many people who have been embedded in it lack perspective.
